active_learning.discussion_prompt: Debate whether 'exceeding authorized access' always equates to intent to defraud under CFAA. Use real cases like US v. Drew (MySpace suicide case) or US v. Nosal (insider access misuse). Categorize actions as fraud vs. non-fraud and vote on policy changes.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Explain the key concepts to a partner without using technical jargon.
active_learning.problem_solving: Given a scenario, apply the framework to solve the problem.

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert educational flashcard generator specializing in cybersecurity law, using university pedagogy (Bloom's Taxonomy, active learning, scaffolding). Generate high-quality flashcards for the topic 'Intent to Defraud Provisions' (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Security And Risk Management > Legal, Regulatory, and Compliance > Legal Frameworks and Systems > Computer Crime and Cybercrime Law > Intent to Defraud Provisions). **Core Content (Web-grounded, complete with voter consensus):** Intent to defraud criminalizes deceptive cyber acts for gain via protected computers (18 U.S.C. § 1030). Key: Intent (knowing deception), Protected Computer (§1030(e)(2): govt/financial/interstate), Unauthorized/Exceeded Access, Damage/Loss. Provisions: §1030(a)(4) - Access w/ intent to defraud + obtain ≥$5k; §1030(a)(7) - Transmit/prevent access w/ intent to defraud. Cases: US v. Nosal, US v. Drew. Standards: NIST SP 800-53 (access controls/MFA), ISO 27001 audits, training. Sources: https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/18/1030; https://www.justice.gov/criminal-fraud/cfaa. **Learning Objectives (Bloom's progression):** [Insert the 6 objectives from above]. **Scaffolding Layers:** Generate ~10 cards per layer. [Insert full scaffolding descriptions]. **Active Learning Integration:** Inspire cards with: [Insert active learning prompts/activities] – e.g., scenario cards link to problem-solving. **Flashcard Generation Rules:** - Use exact schema: JSON array of objects with 'front', 'back' {answer, explanation, reference, active_link, scaffolding_layer, blooms_level}. - Balance: 40% MCQ (3 distractors per protocol: plausible misconception, similar term, edge case), 20% cloze, 20% application scenarios, 10% analysis, 10% evaluation. - Distractors: Strictly follow protocol. - Prioritize higher Bloom's (apply+), ensure measurable/self-testable. - Factual integrity: Cite sources, avoid truncation. - Output ONLY valid JSON array, no extra text.
